electric field while
simultaneously introducing a counter-directional fluid flow. The CCE technology has shown extensive
potential in protein analysis,
metal ion separation, and complex bioinformatics analysis. For example,
Balterms successfully separated and analyzed proteins in egg yolk
yellow protein using CCE combined with mass spectrometry technology,
further verifying the effectiveness of CCE in protein analysis. + + An electrophoresis device
was obtained using COMSOL Multiphysics
to find suitable device parameters and separation environments and
the concentration distributions of Sr and Y ions in the countercurrent
simulation software. COMSOL is a powerful and flexible tool, which
supports custom equations and material properties, and specific physical
fields can be selected for modeling.  2 Principle of Countercurrent
Electrophoresis
Separation The main chamber includes a cylindrical separation
channel. Electrodes
were arranged at both ends of the channel, and a reverse flow field
and an electric field were simultaneously applied. The electrophoretic
velocity obtained by ions in a unit electric field in the direction
of migration is called the mobility or electromobility, denoted as
μ em em 0 F E q E F f r v 2 F f = 6 π η r v = 6 π η r μ em 0 E 3 6 π η r μ em 0 E = q E 4 μ em 0 = q 6 π η r = z e 6 π η r = 2 3 ε η ζ 0 According to these relationships, in
the same solution environment,

various metals and complex ions have different
complex forms. Considering that the electromigration difference of

data, processed by the HySS2009 subroutine in the Hyperquad2013 program, M Figure 2 Evolution of the complexation form of EDTA,
CIT, and 90 90  Figure − 2– − 2– Figure − − 2–  Figure 2 + 2 + − − Figure + 3.3 Summary of Species Behavior under Different
pH Conditions Three pH conditions (2, 4, and 7) were systematically
selected to characterize species behavior, as summarized in Tables 3 Complexes with EDTA,
Sr and Y Species
Behavior, Relative Separation Mass, and Charge at pH Values of 2,
4, and 7 4 Complexes
with CIT, Sr and Y Species
Behavior, Relative Separation Mass, and Charge at pH Values of 2,
4, and 7 Electrophoretic separation
efficiency was governed
by species-specific
electric mobility, determined by charge-to-mass ratios. Comparative
analysis revealed that only Sr species exhibiting superior electric
mobility to their Y counterparts were qualified for CCE applications.
Primary selection criteria focused on identifying Sr species with
absolute charge magnitudes higher than those of Y species (charge
polarity disregarded). This rationale prioritized the investigation
of EDTA-complexed systems at pH 2 and 7, along with CIT-complexed
systems at pH 7. 4 Construction of the Countercurrent
Electrophoresis
Separation Model Modeling is an indispensable method in chemical
and fluid dynamics
research. Establishing a reasonable model involves identifying the
primary factors that affect the movement of objects.  4.1 Variable Parameter Settings Selected
physical parameters of the model at three different working conditions
(with EDTA or CIT as the complexing agent) were listed in Table 3 –4 D  i –9 2 C Sr,0 C Sr,0 C Y,0 3 M Y,eff 5 Model of the Physical
Property Parameter
Values average effective charge or average effective
relative molecular mass working condition 1 working condition 2 working condition 3 unit  z Sr,eff +2 –2 –1.06   z Y,eff 0 –1 0   M Sr,eff 90 378 282.78 g/mol  M Y,eff 379 378 279  4.2 Model Module Settings The main component
of the separation chamber was a cylindrical separation channel with
an inner diameter of 1–5 mm and a length ranging from 300 to
500 mm ( Figure 90 90 3 (A) Simple schematic
of the CCE device: ① narrow separation
channel, ② buffer area, ③ inlet and ④ outlet
of the separation channel, ⑤ right and ⑥ left electrode
chambers, ⑦ right and ⑧ left electrodes, and ⑨
cation-exchange membrane. Model mesh comparison: (B) tetrahedral mesh
and (C) hexahedral mesh. 5 Results
and Discussion 5.1 Mesh Study The
model mesh can directly
determine the solution method of the model and affect the calculation
of the problem, including the solution time, the amount of memory
required to complete the calculations, the best interpolation method
between the solution nodes, and the accuracy of the solution. In order
to improve the accuracy of the solution, the hexahedral mesh modeling
of the separation channel region was specially carried out in this
study ( Figure Figure 5.2 Concentration
Distribution of the Countercurrent
Electrophoresis Device The concentration and separation factor
distributions are shown in Figure 4 Separation factor and ion concentration distribution of
Sr/Y species
in the separation channel for working conditions (A) 1, (B) 2, and
(C) 3 in 1000 V. (D) 90 90 In addition, the separation
factors under the three
working conditions
were calculated. Data normalization employed a constrained scaling
approach 11 y ⁡ axis = min ( n × 10 m , α ) n m Figure 8 4 7 q eff M eff 5.3 Effect of the Temperature Temperature
control is crucial for improving the reproducibility of the experiments.
The heat source of the CCE device comes from Joule heating induced
by the electric field. Condition 2 was chosen as a representative
example to compare the separation factors of the central axis of the
separation channel at different temperatures (20, 40, and 60 °C)
( Figure 5 (A) Separation factor around the central axis of the separation
channel under 20, 40, and 60 °C. (B) Separation factor around
the central axis of the separation channel under 1000, 3000, and 5000
V. (C) Separation factor around the central axis of the separation
channel under different initial strontium concentration conditions.
(D) Fluctuation of the separation factor at the center point of the
device outlet section over time for the three working conditions.
(E) Schematic diagram of cooling water circulation and temperature
measurement points (a, buffer area of the separation chamber; b, cooling
water inlet; and c, outlet). (F) Experimental results and model correction
results of the separation factor under three working conditions. 5.4 Effect of the Voltage Voltage is
a critical factor that affects the electromigration rate. Condition
2 was selected as a representative example, and the separation factor
of the central axis of the separation channel was compared under different
applied voltages (1000, 3000, and 5000 V; Figure 5.5 Effect
of the Initial Strontium Concentration The initial concentration
of the Sr solution can also affect separation.
When working condition 2 was taken as an example, under an electric
field of 1000 V, strontium solutions of 0.01, 0.016, 0.05, and 0.1
mol/L were selected as variables. The separation factors around the
central axis of the separation channel were compared at different
initial Sr concentrations. When we only increase the initial concentration
of strontium, it will disrupt the balance between the electric field
and fluid velocity, resulting in poor separation efficiency or even
an inability to separate. Therefore, we need to provide an appropriate
voltage and flow rate, as shown in Table Figure 6 Voltage and Fluid Flow Rate Data for
Different Initial Sr Concentrations initial Sr concentration (mol/L) voltage (V) flow velocity (m/s) 0.010 1000 0.0008 0.016 1000 0.0001 0.050 2000 0.0001 0.100 5000 0.0001 5.6 Stability Analysis of the Separation Device The system
reached separation equilibrium after 15 s, and the stability
of the CCE separation device was analyzed. The stability of the separation
system was expressed by the change in the separation factor of the
center point of the outlet section of the channel over time, as illustrated
in Figure 5.7 Experimental Verification Non-radioactive
strontium nitrate (0.016 mol/L) and yttrium solutions (0.016/3.9 ×
10 3 Table Figure 5 3 5 Figure 7 Voltage and Fluid
Flow Rate Data for
Different Initial Sr Concentrations voltage (V) current (A) heating power (W) buffer
temperature (°C) cooling water inlet
temperature (°C) cooling water outlet
temperature (°C) cooling power (W) 200 8.52 × 10 –3 1.70 20.0 17.8 18.0 150 400 17.02 × 10 –3 6.81 20.3 17.9 18.3 600 26.65 × 10 –3 15.99 20.4 18.0 18.6 800 34.18 × 10 –3 27.34 20.3 18.0 18.7 1000 47.79 × 10 –3 47.79 20.2 18.0 18.9 It can be seen that there is a certain similarity
between the experimental
results and the simulation results. Similarly, the separation factor
was working condition 1 > working condition 3 > working condition
2. This indicated that the simulation results have a certain correlation
with the actual experiment and have a certain degree of reliability.
However, there are inevitably 2–3 orders of magnitude differences
between experimental data and simulation results. This difference
may stem from some secondary factors overlooked in the simulation.
To get closer to the experimental results, electro-osmotic flow is
introduced into the model, which is discussed in section  Table 8 Summary of Separation Factors for

separation method 9.1 × 10 7  this paper, 2025 countercurrent electrophoresis 8.7 × 10 5  5.8 Model
Modification First, based on
the experimental results, we added a boundary condition: Laminar–wall
condition–electro-osmotic velocity, with an electro-osmotic
migration rate of 7 × 10 –8 2 –1 –1 5 3 5 Figure 6 Conclusion Current research on 90 90 90 90 90 (1) The complexation behaviors of EDTA
and CIT with 90 90 (2) A predictive CCE model was established
and refined through mesh quality optimization. Simulation results
demonstrated uniform distribution profiles and high separation efficiency
across all experimental conditions, with separation factors reaching
9 × 10 8 4 7 6 5 3 5 5 3 5 (3) Device structure
design is a pivotal
area of focus for future research. Effective heat dissipation can
be achieved through the use of thermal conductive materials and cooling
systems, and the smooth flow of the flow field and the problem of
bubble extraction can be addressed through rational device design.
Simultaneously selecting appropriate ligands and constructing a two
ion structure with a significant difference in electromigration is
also of utmost importance. The paper is sponsored by the National Natural Science
Foundation of China (U1867205). The authors declare no
